title: (S)-hydroxynitrile lyase
text:
("S")-hydroxynitrile lyase (, "(S)-cyanohydrin producing hydroxynitrile lyase", "(S)-oxynitrilase", "(S)-HbHNL", "(S)-MeHNL", "hydroxynitrile lyase", "oxynitrilase", "HbHNL", "MeHNL", "(S)-selective hydroxynitrile lyase", "(S)-cyanohydrin carbonyl-lyase (cyanide forming)", <a href="hydroxynitrilase">hydroxynitrilase</a>) is an <a href="enzyme">enzyme</a> with <a href="List%20of%20enzymes">systematic name</a> "(S)-cyanohydrin lyase (cyanide forming)". This enzyme <a href="catalysis">catalyses</a> the interconversion between <a href="cyanohydrin">cyanohydrin</a>s and the <a href="carbonyl">carbonyl</a> compounds derived from the cyanohydrin with free <a href="cyanide">cyanide</a>, as in the following two <a href="chemical%20reaction">chemical reaction</a>s:
In nature, the liberation of cyanide serves as a defense mechanism against <a href="herbivores">herbivores</a> and microbial attack in <a href="plant">plant</a>s. Hydroxynitrile lyases of the <a href="alpha/beta%20hydrolase%20fold">α/β hydrolase fold</a> are closely related to <a href="esterase">esterase</a>s. All members of the α/β hydrolase fold contain a conserved <a href="catalytic%20triad">catalytic triad</a> (<a href="nucleophile">nucleophile</a>-<a href="histidine">histidine</a>-<a href="aspartate">aspartate</a>). The <a href="nucleophile">nucleophile</a> in this case is a <a href="serine">serine</a>. In contrast to esterases, <a href="serine%20proteases">serine proteases</a>, <a href="lipases">lipases</a> and other enzymes in this family, the nucleophile in hydroxynitrile lyases functions as a <a href="proton%20acceptor">proton acceptor</a>. Key <a href="amino%20acid">amino acid</a> residues in this reaction are the <a href="lysine">lysine</a> at position 236 and the <a href="threonine">threonine</a> at position 11. Lys236 helps to orient the <a href="substrate%20%28biochemistry%29">substrate</a> while Thr11 serves to block the <a href="oxyanion%20hole">oxyanion hole</a> that would convert the enzyme into an esterase.
Commonly studied ("S")-selective hydroxynitrile lyases include MeHNL from "<a href="Manihot%20esculenta">Manihot esculenta</a>" and HbHNL from "<a href="Hevea%20brasiliensis">Hevea brasiliensis</a>". ("R")-selective hydroxynitrile lyases have also been found to exist in "<a href="Arabidopsis%20thaliana">Arabidopsis thaliana</a>" (AtHNL). AtHNL is thought to catalyze this reaction by a different mechanism.
Not all hydroxynitrile lyases belong to the α/β hydrolase family. PaHNL (<a href="Prunus%20amygdalus">Prunus amygdalus</a>), ("R")-selective like AtHNL, uses a <a href="Flavin%20adenine%20dinucleotide">flavin</a> <a href="cofactor%20%28biochemistry%29">cofactor</a> to <a href="catalyze">catalyze</a> <a href="cyanogenesis">cyanogenesis</a>.
Natural Substrates of Hydroxynitrile Lyases.
<a href="Acetone%20cyanohydrin">Acetone cyanohydrin</a> has been determined to be the natural substrate of HbHNL, though HbHNL also shows activity with <a href="mandelonitrile">mandelonitrile</a>, the natural substrate of PaHNL. The cleavage of mandelonitrile into <a href="benzaldehyde">benzaldehyde</a> and <a href="cyanide">cyanide</a> is what produces the characteristic <a href="amaretto">amaretto</a> smell of almonds. The natural substrate of AtHNL is unknown as no <a href="cyanohydrin">cyanohydrin</a>s have been detected in "Arabidopis thaliana".
Unnatural Substrates.
In addition to cyanohydrin cleavage, HNLs have been found to catalyze the <a href="nitroaldol%20reaction">nitroaldol reaction</a> at low levels.
